data.description: While the nation is still waiting to see if Congress will take up criminal justice reform, states have been quietly getting the job done. A new Urban Institute report shows that states participating in the Justice Reinvestment Initiative (JRI) have saved over a billion dollars thus far through smart...
data.message: ICYMI: Right on Crime’s Marc Levin on how states have and continue to lead the way on justice reform.
data.name: How the states can show the way to criminal justice reform

data.description: Our broken criminal justice system costs taxpayers billions per year as mandatory minimums keep prisons full of non-violent people.
data.message: LTE in Iowa’s The Des Moines Register on Senator Chuck Grassley’s support for justice reform: "We applaud him for his persistence on this important issue. Our broken criminal justice system is costing taxpayers over $80 billion per year as mandatory minimum sentences have filled our prisons with non-violent people who don't need to be serving long sentences.”
data.name: Grassley is dedicated to criminal justice reform

data.description: Over the course of 25 years, women’s incarceration has increased drastically, and has reached a point where females are jailed at a rate of nearly 150 percent when compared to men. According to the ACLU, there are now more than 200,000 women behind bars and more than one million women on probation a...
data.message: “Over the course of 25 years, women’s incarceration has increased drastically, and has reached a point where females are jailed at a rate of nearly 150 percent when compared to men.”
data.name: Incarcerated Women Largely Ignored in Criminal Justice Reform - IVN.us

data.message: We applaud Governor Eric Greitens for making justice reform a top priority for his first year in office.

data.description: The Illinois Senate passed a bill Tuesday giving judges more control over sentencing and beginning a process to provide more funding trauma recovery services for violent crime victims. Both houses passed a bill addressing these measures, which is on its way to the governor’s desk. The bill works tow...
data.message: The Illinois Senate just passed legislation to improve sentencing practices:
data.name: Illinois Senate passes criminal justice reform bill

data.message:
Last year, 73% of voters in Missouri agreed that the main goal of our justice system should be “rehabilitating those who are incarcerated to become productive, law-abiding citizens.” We look forward to working with Governor Eric Greitens to improve the lives of those behind bars and helping them come home. You can catch his first State of the State address here: http://www.mo.gov/live/

For more data on our Missouri polling click here: http://bit.ly/2j6kvJP
data.name: Timeline Photos

data.description: Indiana’s over-reliance on incarceration is a costly and questionable solution to the state’s public safety challenges. This infographic breaks it down.
data.message: Between 2000 and 2010, Indiana’s prison population increased by 47%, beginning with 19,309 prisoners and growing to 28,389. It is clear that the state of Indiana is in need of smart reforms. We are calling on Governor Eric Holcomb to make justice reform a priority for the state of Indiana in 2017. You can watch the address here: http://bit.ly/2j6XXIS #StatesLead
data.name: Indiana’s Criminal Justice System: What You Should Know

data.message: Governor Rick Snyder of Michigan has been supportive of justice reform efforts since taking office. Tonight, we're looking forward to seeing if he continues on the path towards reform in his second to last State of the State to address. Click here to watch the address: http://bit.ly/2jGwm1G #StatesLead
data.name: Timeline Photos

data.description: In some circles, it’s called a shared sentence.For each parent incarcerated, there’s at least one forgotten victim: a child.While mom or dad is behind bars, the child’s sentence is to live with the absence of a parent, whether for days, years or a...
data.message: “About 5 percent of New Hampshire children – approximately 13,570 of all minors in the state – have an incarcerated parent. Of those children, 2,930 have a parent in one of the state’s three prisons; the remaining are children of parents in county jails."
data.name: Parenting from Prison: Children of inmates have become the forgotten victims of crime
